TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON , a NORP national , is a lawyer who practises in GPE . At the material time , he was facing criminal proceedings in ORG ( ORG ) in connection with his activities as the lawyer of various members of ORG ( ORG ) .

CARDINAL . Initially he was represented by CARDINAL lawyers of his choice : PERSON , practising in GPE , and PERSON , having his office in GPE . Subsequently , on DATE , they were designated , at his request , to represent him as court - appointed defence counsel . The applicant had , moreover , chosen CARDINAL further lawyers to assist in his defence , CARDINAL of whom were LANGUAGE , but they did not participate in the criminal proceedings in question here .
CARDINAL . On DATE , on an application by the prosecuting authority , the President of ORG designated as third court - appointed defence counsel , PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

CARDINAL . Mr Croissant raised objections both to the appointment of a third defence counsel itself and to the choice of the person concerned . He objected in particular that Mr PERSON was a member of ORG ( ORG ) , while he was fundamentally opposed to that party . He requested either that the decision appointing PERSON be annulled or that the latter be replaced by PERSON , who also had his office in GPE .
PERSON for his part asked to be relieved of his duties in the case .
ORG dismissed both applications on DATE .

On the first point it considered that it had been necessary to appoint a third defence counsel to ensure that the trial would take its course according to the principles laid down in LAW and , in any event , that the accused was adequately represented throughout the trial , having regard to its possible length and to the size and complexity of the case .

As to the other objection , it agreed that when selecting a lawyer to be appointed as defence counsel the court should , as a rule , endeavour to choose a lawyer in whom the defendant places confidence . This rule was formulated for cases where the defendant has no defence counsel and the court must appoint CARDINAL . However , at Mr Croissant ’s request , the court had appointed CARDINAL defence counsel who enjoyed his full confidence . Nevertheless , when selecting the third court - appointed defence counsel , the court had not only taken into consideration which lawyer would offer the best guarantees for a proper and effective defence , having regard to the subject - matter of the trial , the factual and legal complexity of the case and the personality of the defendant . It had also tried to choose CARDINAL in whom the defendant would probably be able to place confidence .

Taking into account all the circumstances which were relevant for assessing whether PERSON was a suitable person to defend PERSON , the court held that the fact that PERSON was a member of the ORG did not justify revoking his appointment : in so far as the defendant might wish the defence to make a sharp attack on the politics of this party , the other court - appointed counsel offered all the guarantees . PERSON too had expressed the opinion that he was in a position to appear for the defendant in spite of their political differences .
Finally , PERSON was defending CARDINAL of Mr Croissant ’s former employees in other proceedings and the possibility of a conflict of interests could not be ruled out .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) upheld this decision . It recalled that , according to the case - law of ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht ) , an appointment to act as defence counsel could and should only be revoked when its purpose - that is , to ensure that the accused will be adequately defended and the proceedings properly conducted - is seriously endangered . On similar grounds as the first - instance court , it held that Mr Croissant had not established that this requirement was met in respect of Mr PERSON ’s appointment .

As to the appointment of a third defence counsel , the court found nothing to criticise . To appoint a further defence counsel having his office within ORG jurisdiction had been objectively justified by reason of the length of the proceedings , which could not be predicted accurately , and the size and complexity of the case .

As to PERSON request to be discharged from the case , the court found that unjustified too . Neither Mr Croissant nor PERSON maintained , nor was there anything to show , that the relations between them were so strained or they had quarrelled in such a way as to make a proper defence impossible .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , PERSON tried to secure the additional assistance of PERSON , by choosing him as defence counsel , but to no avail . Under Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure , an accused may not be represented by CARDINAL such lawyers ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and he had already retained CARDINAL counsel of his own choice ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
At the trial , which lasted DATE , the applicant was represented by the CARDINAL court - appointed defence counsel .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convicted the applicant of supporting a criminal organisation and sentenced him to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment ; he was also barred from practising his profession for DATE and ordered to pay the costs and expenses , including those which he had been compelled to incur himself .
On DATE ORG ( ORG ) dismissed PERSON appeal on points of law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the costs office ( ORG ) of ORG set the costs and expenses at ORG , including DM CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL for the fees and disbursements of the CARDINAL court - appointed defence counsel . In an additional bill ( GPE ) of DATE it fixed the final amount at ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL , DM CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL of which represented the ORG fees and disbursements . The amount payable in respect of PERSON was DM CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged an objection ( GPE ) against this assessment , which he considered to be incompatible with Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( c ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW . He argued that once free legal assistance had been granted no payment could subsequently be demanded , so that he was under no obligation to pay the court - appointed lawyers and in particular PERSON , who had been imposed on him .

On DATE ORG dismissed the objection ; it referred to the opinion which prevailed in NORP case - law and literature on the subject , which opinion had been endorsed by the ORG in a decision of CARDINAL DATE ( application no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , Decisions and Reports CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Mr Croissant lodged an appeal ( Beschwerde ) in ORG , based on the same grounds . He stressed their particular relevance to PERSON , who had been appointed against PERSON will .

On DATE the appeal was allowed in respect of CARDINAL minor items ( DM CARDINAL in total ) , but was dismissed as to the main issue . ORG held that the designation of a third court - appointed defence counsel had corresponded to a pressing need - ensuring an adequate defence - , on account of the scope and complexity of the case and in view of the probable duration of the trial . If the court , when making the appointment , had also purported to secure that the trial would take its legal course , it had rightly done so since that was a legitimate interest to be taken into account as well . As to the applicant ’s arguments based on Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( c ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW , the court endorsed the reasons given by ORG . It added that the financial means of the defendant are immaterial for deciding whether or not the court should appoint a defence counsel . The question whether a convicted person is able to pay only arises after the criminal proceedings have ended .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , sitting as a panel of CARDINAL judges , refused to entertain Mr Croissant ’s constitutional appeal ( ORG ) , taking the view that it had no prospect of success . In the light of the ORG ’s case - law , the court considered that it did not follow from Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( c ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW that legal assistance was definitively provided free . It held that a convicted person ’s obligation to pay costs and expenses derived from the fact that proceedings had been brought as a result of his own conduct . The principle of the " social state " ( Sozialstaatsprinzip ) and the right to a fair trial no doubt guaranteed that , where necessary , legal assistance be accorded to an indigent accused , but they did not require him to be definitively dispensed from paying the fees incurred . The law on legal costs and expenses made available other possibilities ( arrangements for payment or stay of execution ) to take effective account of the financial difficulties of the convicted person . Finally , ORG conclusion regarding the necessity of appointing PERSON as the third lawyer ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) was coherent and in any event had not been arbitrary .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant had already requested an extension of the time - limit for payment ( Stundung ) , but this was refused by the President of ORG ( ORG ) on DATE . After a first appeal ( Beschwerde ) had failed , his further appeal ( PERSON ) was allowed on CARDINAL DATE , when ORG quashed the earlier decisions and remitted the matter to ORG . It considered that a decision to grant such an extension was primarily intended to facilitate the rehabilitation of a debtor who had already served his sentence . It was accordingly necessary to take account of the appellant ’s argument that a rejection of his request would force him to make a declaration of assets ( PERSON ) and would hamper his efforts to resume practising as a lawyer . It was also necessary to bear in mind that the applicant had agreed to the inspection of his documents and accounts by a member of ORG , in order to assess his income , and that ORG had proposed to ask him to make a confidential statement under oath before a notary instead of a declaration of assets . Even though granting the extension would mean in reality that a large part of the debt would remain unpaid indefinitely , that did not justify a refusal ; in any event it was unlikely that the total amount could ever be recovered . It was therefore necessary to reconsider the question and to determine whether it was possible to authorise smaller payments by instalments .

CARDINAL . As a result , the President of ORG granted several extensions of the time - limit , on the most recent occasion until DATE . However , in DATE , on his own initiative , Mr Croissant started to pay ORG DATE , on the condition that this sum not be used to pay the court - appointed lawyers .

CARDINAL . In DATE , DATE and DATE he had unsuccessfully sought to have the debt cancelled . A fourth such request , filed on DATE , led to an order made by the President of ORG on DATE . Whilst dismissing the remainder of the application , he reserved , pending the ruling of ORG , his decision on the payment of the fees and expenses of the court - appointed lawyers .
